resource.chars: Emit such a sweet scent
As does the holy crown
That God wore, and the true cross
Where he received the mortal wound
In order to redeem all of our sins.
This is where Fauvel decided to establish himself.
This is where Fauvel desired to celebrate his wedding.
He did not invite or call for
Bishops or abbots bearing crosses:
He wanted that, without declining,
Carnality his friend come,
For he could not do without her.
Fornication, Adultery
Come there, without saying anything against it.
Cupid will come as well as Venus.
Of such people, no one remains behind.
Gluttony and Drinking come
And hope that they are not alone.
Inebriation, Excess and Ribaldry
Come with them, as well as Lechery,
Anger, Fault, Quarrel, Homicide,
Hypocrisy, Pride, Acedia,
Theft, Discord, Fury,
Heresy and Sodomy,
Covetousness, Envy, and Lie
Do not come there only in dreams.
Slander, Deceit, Trickery,
Greed and Felony,
Ruse and False Seeming
Do not go to the party walking,
Nor all the rest of the company
Of the lineage, counsel and household
Of Fauvel, which I have described elsewhere.
All come joyfully
Both the lenders and the usurers
Come down these paths together.
They want to be acquainted, forever, with
Those gracious and agreeable people
Who come. They come from day to day
And proceed along the paths from all directions.
In the city mentioned above,
Each one looks for a place to lodge.
Moreover, since I remember
Something concerning the palace,
I say that it is both a palace and a castle
And there is none like it in the world,
For there are smaller castles
In the surrounding area—
More than ten, corresponding completely
With the palace and giving it assistance.
On the two sides of the main doors
Of the palace, there are very strong constructions,
And two bridges of very beautiful design.
Even the whole kingdom of Castille
Is not worth what these are worth!
They diverge from believing the truth.
Some surely do not believe this, without a doubt,
For I am telling the whole truth.
One is situated towards the right at noon,
The other towards the north. And I say
That one goes on these bridges that I describe here
To access the city, which is seated
Near the island and the area near the cathedral,
In a very noble manner.
It is the richest city in the world
And the place where riches abound the most.
It is called Hope.
Only the distance of the bridges
Separates it from the palace described above.
Each man cries out and does not stop crying:
“From the palace named Hopelessness
Much evil will come, as I expect,
Since Fauvel rejoices!
Lady of the sky, through what fault
Is now base what used to be
Called sweet paradise?
Is it not very strange
That this assembly will be held there?
Is there a greater misfortune
Than to see such a country metamorphosed in this way?
Is there a greater spell
Than that things proceed in this way?
Is this not more than a misfortune,
When from the place where faith
Should reign, Fauvel makes his abode,
Because of which everyone brays and cries
Now that he lives there completely?
Oh, Fortune! She turns so sweetly
Your wheel when it does not fall faster
Onto him [?]! Certainly, this is a great sin!
Both, as those who have seen it say,
Are situated on a great island
In the palace and the area around the cathedral
And, through a noble subtlety,
One of the edges of the island is occupied crosswise
By the palace, when one goes towards
The west, in a beautiful way.
And the other edge
Of the cité, towards the Orient,
Includes the mother church in a very noble way.
Even though I am pained, sad and mournful
Because Fauvel turns everything upside down,
The subject that I have taken up,
I want to pursue, and finish this book quickly.
The jug goes to the water so often
That it falls to the ground and is broken.
Therefore I tell you, melancholic and defeated,
That this false one who conquers everyone everywhere,
Because of his evil, he knows that he will be conquered
And will end up imprisoned.
Before he considers himself conquered,
He has undertaken to behave himself
In an even more presumptuous manner
Than he did at the beginning.
All of his relatives, whom he has invited
Through letters, have come.
I have told you the names of several
Above, so I do not want to drone on
To repeat them again
And it would take too long to write
The names of this multitude
Of wicked and unpleasant people.
They have entered the great halls,
Making merry and having large parties.
They found Lady Vainglory
And greeted her courteously.
Each one looks at her with great attention
And she deceives them and lures them
And makes them fall asleep in the great pleasures
Of beautiful rooms and beds
And riches which flee like shadows
But which weigh one down, the more one possesses them.
